newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan drafts rules for investments in China.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan drafts rules for investments in China.

text.p: Taiwan has drafted a new set of criteria which may be used to regulate the level of local investment in rival China, economics officials said on Saturday.

"The criteria were drafted by a group of scholars and experts at the request of the economics ministry, and we might use them to screen our indirect investment in mainland China in the future," an Investment Commission spokesman said.
"But before we use them, we would first seek consensus from government officials, businessmen and lawmakers," the official told Reuters.

The criteria would help determine if a Taiwanese investment in a Chinese industry, and the possible transfer of necessary technology, would in the long run hurt similar industries in Taiwan, the official said.
The criteria would also set a ceiling on the amount of investment in China, which the official said would affect mostly larger Taiwan firms. He declined to give further details.
Taiwan, which has banned direct contact with China since the end of a civil war that split them in 1949, has been concerned that its economy may become overdependent on China.
More than 30,000 Taiwan firms have invested an estimated US$30 billion in China since an unofficial thaw in bilateral relations begain in the late 1980s.
Indirect trade with the mainland has become a major source of trade surplus for Taiwan since the early 1990s.

On Friday, Taiwan's parliament also approved revisions to the Taiwan-mainland relation act to grant a three-month grace period for local firms making unauthorised investment in China, encouraging them to report such activities.
